titleStmt.title: The Queen of Corinth1617
titleStmt.author: Field, Nathan; Massinger, Philip; Fletcher, John

editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

respStmt.resp: Incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words were reviewed and in many cases fixed by
respStmt.name: Madeline Burg

respStmt.resp: Tokenization and linguistic annotation using MorphAdorner and NUPOS 2.0 were provided by
respStmt.name: Philip R. Burns

respStmt.resp: With the help of Thomas L. Berger's Index of Characters in Early Modern English Drama Printed Plays, 1500-1660 speech prefixes were mapped to unique "who" attributes of sp elements by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: A provisional, rudimentry, and algorithmically produced castlist was added as a new div in the back listing each role with their number of speeches sorted from high to low by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

respStmt.resp: Project co-ordination and review of textual changes and linguistic annotation by
respStmt.name: Martin Mueller

note.p: "Never printed before, and now published by the authours originall copies"
First folio; includes the plays not hitherto printed, except the Wild-goose chase, which was missing, but recovered and printed in 1652. Cf. NUC pre-1956.
"The Epistle dedicatorie" is signed by John Lowin, Joseph Taylor, and eight others; "To the reader" signed by Ja. Shirley, who is usually regarded as the editor.
For complete contents of this edition, see NUC pre-1956 imprints.
Reproduction of original in Harvard University Libraries.

div.head: The Queen of Corinth,

sp.speaker: Era.
sp.l: The general is returned then?

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: With much honour.

sp.speaker: Sol.
sp.l: And peace concluded with the prince of Argos?

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: To the Queen's wishes: the conditions signed
So far beyond her hopes, to the advantage
Of Corinth, and the good of all her subjects;
That though Leonidas our brave general
Ever came home a fair and great example,
He never yet returned, or with less loss
Or more deserved honour.

sp.speaker: Era.
sp.l: Have you not heard
The motives to this general good?

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: The main one
Was admiration first in young Agenor,
(For by that name we know the prince of Argos)
Of our Leonidas wisdom, and his valour,
Which though an enemy, first in him bred wonder;
That liking, love succeeded that, which was
Followed by a desire to be a friend
Upon what terms soever to such goodness;
They had an interview; and that their friendship
Might with our peace be ratified, 'twas concluded,
Agenor yielding up all such strong places
As he held in our territories, should receive
(With a sufficient dower, paid by the Queen)
The fair Merione for his wife.

sp.speaker: Era.
sp.l: But how
Approves the Queen of this? since we well know,
Nor was her highness ignorant, that her son
The prince Theanor made love to this lady,
And in the noblest way.

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: Which she allowed of,
And I have heard from some familiar with
Her nearest secrets, she so deeply prized her
Being from an infant trained up in her service,
(Or to speak better, rather her own creature)
She once did say, that if the prince should steal
A marriage without her leave, or knowledge,
With this Merione, with a little suit
She should grant both their pardons: where as now
To show herself forsooth a Spartan lady,
And that 'tis in her power, now it concerns
The common good, not alone to subdue
Her own affections, but command her sons;
She has not only forced him with rough threats
To leave his mistress, but compelled him when
Agenor made his entrance into Corinth
To wait upon his rival.

sp.speaker: Sos.
sp.l: Can it be
The prince should sit down with this wrong?

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: I know not,
I am sure I should not.

sp.speaker: Era.
sp.l: Trust me nor I,
A mother is a name, but put in balance
With a young wench 'tis nothing; where did you leave him?

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: Near Vesta's temple, for there he dismissed me,
And full of troubled thoughts, calling for Crates:
He went with him, but whither or to what purpose
I am a stranger.

sp.speaker: Era.
sp.l: They are come back Neanthes.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: I like the place well.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: Well sir? it is built
As if the architect had been a prophet,
And fashioned it alone for this night's action;
The vaults so hollow, and the walls so strong,
As Dian there might suffer violence,
And with loud shrieks in vain call Jove to help her;
Or should he hear, his thunder could not find
An entrance to it.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: I give up myself
Wholly to thy direction, worthiest Crates;
And yet the desperate cure that we must practise
Is in itself so foul, and full of danger,
That I stand doubtful whether 'twere more manly
To die not seeking help, or that help being
So deadly, to pursue it.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: To those reasons
I have already urged, I will add these.
For but consider sir —

sp.speaker: Era.
sp.l: It is of weight
Whate'er it be, that with such vehement action,
Of eye, hand, foot, nay all his body's motion,
Crates incites the prince to.

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: Then observe,
With what variety of passions he
Receives his reasons; now he's pale, and shakes
For fear or anger; now his natural red
Comes back again, and with a pleasing smile
He seems to entertain it; 'tis resolved on
Be it what 'twill: to his ends may it prosper
Though the state sink for't.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: Now you are a prince
Fit to rule others, and in shaking off
The bonds in which your mother fetters you
Discharge your debt to nature, she's your guide,
Follow her boldly sir.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: I am confirmed,
Fall what may fall,

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: Yet still disguise your malice
In your humility.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: I am instructed.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: Though in your heart there rage a thousand tempests,
All calmness in your looks.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: I shall remember.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: And at no hand, though these are used as agents
Acquaint them with your purpose till the instant
That we employ them; 'tis not fit they have
Time to consider, when 'tis done, reward
Or fear will keep them silent: yet you may
Grace them as you pass by, 'twill make them surer,
And greedier to deserve you.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: I'll move only
As you would have me: good day gentlemen;
Nay, spare this ceremonious form of duty
To him that brings love to you, equal love,
And is in nothing happier, than in knowing
It is returned by you; we are as one.

sp.speaker: Sos.
sp.l: I am o'erjoyed, I know not
How to reply: but —

sp.speaker: Era.
sp.l: Hang all butts; my lord,
For this your bounteous favour —

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: Let me speak,
If to feed vultures hereafter the halter
Has done his part, or if there be a hell
To take a swinge or two there, may deserve this.

sp.speaker: Sos.
sp.l: We are ready.

sp.speaker: Era.
sp.l: Try us any way.

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: Put us to it.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: What jewels I have in you?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: Have these souls,
That for a good look, and a few kind words
Part with their essence?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Since you will compel me
To put that to the trial, which I doubt not,
Crates may be suddenly will instruct you
How, and in what to show your loves; obey him
As you would bind me to you.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: 'Tis well grounded;
Leave me to rear the building.

sp.speaker: Nean.
sp.l: We will do.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: I know it.

sp.speaker: Era.
sp.l: Any thing you'll put us to. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Sister, I reap the harvest of my labours
In your preferment, be you worthy of it,
And with an open bosom entertain
A greater fortune than my love durst hope for;
Be wise, and welcome it: play not the coy
And foolish wanton, with the offered bounties
Of him that is a prince. I was wooed for you,
And won Merione: then if you dare
Believe the object that took me was worthy,
Or trust my judgement, in me think you were
Courted, sued to, and conquered.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Noble brother,
I have, and still esteem you as a father,
And will as far obey you; my heart speaks it:
And yet without your anger give me leave
To say, that in the choice of that on which
All my life's joys or sorrows have dependence,
It had been fit ere you had made a full
And absolute grant of me to any other,
I should have used mine own eyes, or at least
Made you to understand, whether it were
Within my power to make a second gift
Of my poor self.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I know what 'tis you point at,
The prince Theanos' love; let not that cheat you;
His vows were but mere courtship; all his service
But practise how to entrap a credulous lady:
Or grant it serious, yet you must remember
He's not to love but where the Queen his mother
Must give allowance, which to you is barred up:
And therefore study to forget that ever
You cherished such a hope.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I would I could.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: But brave Agenor, who is come in person
To celebrate this marriage, for your love
Forgives the forfeit of ten thousand lives,
That must have fallen under the sword of war
Had not this peace been made; which general good
Both countries owe to his affection to you:
Oh happy sister, ask this noble lady
Your bosom friend (Since I fail in my credit)
What palm Agenor's name above all princes
That Greece is proud of carries, and with lustre.

sp.speaker: Rel.
sp.l: Indeed fame gives him out of excellent;
And friend, I doubt not but when you shall see him
He'll so appear to you. Art sure 'tis he?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: As I live madam —

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Virtue enable me to contain my joy.
'Tis my euphanes.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: And he's in health?

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: Most certainly madam,

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: I'll see him instantly.
So prithee tell him. Exit Ser.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I yield myself too weak
In argument to oppose you: you may lead me
Whither you please.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: 'Tis answered like my sister;
And if in him you find not ample cause
To pray for me, and daily on your knees,
Conclude I have no judgement.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: May it prove so:
Friend, shall we have your company?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Two hours hence
I will not fail you.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: At your pleasure madam. Exit leo. and Mer.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Could I in one word speak a thousand welcomes
(And hearty ones) you have 'em: fie, my hand,
We stand at no such distance, by my life
The parting kiss you took before your travel
Is yet a virgin on my lips, preserved
With as much care as I would do my fame,
To entertain your wished return.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: Best lady,
That I do honour you, and with as much reason
As ever man did virtue; that I love you,
Yet look upon you with that reverence
As holy men behold the sun, the stars,
The temples, and their gods, they all can witness;
And that you have deserved this duty from me;
The life, and means of life, for which I owe you,
Commands me to profess it, since my fortune
Affords no other payment.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Good Euphanes, where benefits are ill conferred,
I had thought,
That for the trifling courtesies as I call them,
(Though you give them another name) you had
Made ample satisfaction in th' acceptance,
And therefore did presume you had brought home
Some other language.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: No one I have learned
Yields words sufficient to express your goodness;
Nor can I ever choose another theme
And not be thought unthankful.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Pray you no more
As you respect me.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: That charm is too powerful
For me to disobey it: 'tis your pleasure,
And not my boldness madam.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Good Euphanes,
Believe I am not one of those weak ladies,
That (Barren of all inward worth) are proud
Of what they cannot truly call their own,
Their birth or fortune, which are things without them,
Nor in this will I imitate the world,
Whose greater part of men think when they give
They purchase bondmen, not make worthy friends:
By all that's good I swear, I never thought
My great estate was an addition to me,
Or that your wants took from you.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: There are few
So truly understanding or themselves
Or what they do possess.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Good Euphanes,
Where benefits
Are ill conferred as to unworthy men,
That turn them to bad uses, the bestower
For wanting judgement how, and on whom to place them,
Is partly guilty: but when we do favours
To such as make them grounds on which they build
Their noble actions, there we improve our fortunes
To the most fair advantage. If I speak
Too much, though I confess I speak well,
Prithee remember 'tis a woman's weakness,
And than thou wilt forgive it.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: You speak nothing
But what would well become the wisest man:
And that by you delivered is so pleasing
That I could hear you ever.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Fly not from
Your word, for I arrest it: and will now
Express myself a little more, and prove
That whereas you profess yourself my debtor,
That I am yours.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: Your ladyship then must use
Some sophistry I never heard of.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: By plain reasons,
For look you, had you never sunk beneath
Your wants, or if those wants had found supply
From Crates, your unkind and covetous brother,
Or any other man, I then had missed
A subject upon which I worthily
Might exercise my bounty: whereas now
By having happy opportunity
To furnish you before, and in your travels,
With all conveniencies that you thought useful,
That gold which would have rusted in my coffers
Being thus employed, has rendered me a partner
In all your glorious actions. And whereas
Had you not been, I should have died a thing.
Scarce known, or soon forgotten: there's no trophy
In which Euphanes for his worth is mentioned,
But there you have been careful to remember,
That all the good you did came from Beliza.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: That was but thankfulness.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: 'Twas such an honour,
And such a large return for the poor trash.
I ventured with you, that if I should part
With all that I possess, and myself too
In satisfaction for it, 'twere still short
Of your deservings.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: You o'erprize them madam.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: The Queen herself hath given me gracious thanks
In your behalf, for she hath heard Euphanes
How gallantly you have maintained her honour
In all the courts of Greece: and rest assured,
(Though yet unknown) when I present you to her,
Which I will do this evening, you shall find
That she intends good to you.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: Worthiest lady,
Since all you labour for is the advancement
Of him that will live ever your poor servant,
He must not contradict it.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Here's your brother,
'Tis strange to see him here.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: You are welcome home sir,
(Your pardon madam) I had thought my house,
Considering who I am, might have been worthy
Of your first visit.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: 'Twas not open to me
When last I saw you; and to me 'tis wonder
That absence which still renders men forgotten
Should make my presence wished for.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: That's not it,
Your too kind brother understanding that
You stand in no need of him, is bold to offer
His entertainment.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: He had never wanted,
Or yours, or your assistance, had he practised
The way he might have taken, to have commanded
Whatever I call mine,

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: I studied many,
But could find none.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: You would not find yourself sir,
Or in yourself what was from you due to me:
The privilege my birth bestowed upon me
Might challenge some regard.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: You had all the land sir,
What else did you expect? and I am certain
You kept such strong guards to preserve it yours
I could force nothing from you.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: Did you ever
Demand help from me?

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: My wants have, and often,
With open mouths, but you nor heard, nor saw them;
May be you looked I should petition to you
As you went to your horse; flatter your servants,
To play the brokers for my furtherance,
Sooth your worse humours, act the parasite
On all occasions, write my name with theirs
That are but one degree removed from slaves,
Be drunk when you would have me, than wench with you,
Or play the pander; enter into quarrels
Although unjustly grounded, and defend them
Because they were yours; these are the tyrannies
Most younger brother's groan beneath; yet bear them
From the insulting heir, selling their freedoms
At a less rate than what the state allows,
The salary of base and common strumpets:
For my part, ere on such low terms I feed
Upon a brother's trencher, let me die
The beggar's death, and starve.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: 'Tis bravely spoken,
Did what you do rank with it.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Why, what does he
You would not wish were yours?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: I'll tell you lady,
Since you rise up his advocate, and boldly,
(For now I find, and plainly, in whose favour
My love and service to you was neglected)
For all your wealth, nay, add to that your beauty,
And put your virtues in if you have any,
I would not yet be pointed at, as he is,
For the fine courtier, the woman's man,
That tells my lady storeys, dissolves riddles,
Ushers her to coach, lies at her feet
At solemn masks, applauding what she laughs at;
Reads her asleep a nights, and takes his oath
Upon her pantofles, that all excellence
In other madams do but zany hers:
These you are perfect in, and yet these take not
Or from your birth or freedom.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: Should another
Say this, my deeds, not looks should show —

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Contemn it:
His envy feigns this, and he's but reporter,
Without a second, of his own dry fancies.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: Yes madam, the whole city speaks it with me,
And though it may distaste, 'tis certain you
Are brought into the scene, and with him censured;
For you are given out for the provident lady,
That not to be unfurnished for her pleasures
(As without them to what vain use is greatness)
Have made choice of an able man, a young man
Of an Herculean back to do you service,
And one you may command too, that is active,
And does what you would have him.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: You are foul mouthed.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: That can speak well, write verses too, and good ones,
Sharp and conceited, whose wit you may lie with
When his performance fails him; one you have
Maintained abroad to learn new ways to please you.
And by the gods you well reward him for it,
No night (In which while you lie sick and panting)
He watches by you but is worth a talent:
No conference in your coach which is not paid with
A scarlet suit; this the poor people mutter,
Though I believe, for I am bound to do so,
A lady of your youth, that feeds high too,
And a most exact lady, may do all this
Out of virtuous love, the last bought vizard
That lechery purchased.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: Not a word beyond this,
The reverence I owe to that one womb
In which we both were embryons, makes me suffer
What's past; but if continued —

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Stay your hand,
The Queen shall right mine honour.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: Let him do it,
It is but marrying him; and for your anger
Know that I slight it: when your goddess here
Is weary of your sacrifice, as she will be,
You know my house, and there amongst my servants
Perhaps you'll find a livery. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Be not moved,
I know the rancour of his disposition,
And turn it on himself by laughing at it,
And in that let me teach you.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: I learn gladly. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena tertia.
div.stage: Enter Neanthes, Sosines, and Eraton, severally.

sp.speaker: Nea.
sp.l: You are met unto my wishes, if you ever
Desired true mirth so far as to adventure
To die with the extremity of laughter,
I come before the object that will do it;
Or let me live your fool.

sp.speaker: Sos.
sp.l: Who is't Neanthes?

sp.speaker: Nea.
sp.l: Lamprias the usurer's son.

sp.speaker: Era.
sp.l: Lamprias? the youth
Of six and fifty?

sp.speaker: Sos.
sp.l: That was sent to travel
By rich Beliza, till he came to age,
And was fit for a wife?

sp.speaker: Nea.
sp.l: The very same,
This gallant with his guardian, and his tutor,
(And of the three who is most fool I know not)
Are newly come to Corinth, I'll not stale them
By giving up their characters, but leave you
To make your own discoveries: here they are sir.

sp.speaker: Tutor.
sp.l: That leg a little higher; very well.
Now put your face into the traveler's posture;
Exceeding good.

sp.speaker: Uncle.
sp.l: Do you mark how they admire him?

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.l: They will be all my scholars, when they know
And understand him truly.

sp.speaker: Era.
sp.l: Phoebus guard me
From this new Python.

sp.speaker: Sos.
sp.l: How they have trimmed him up
Like an old reveller?

sp.speaker: Nea.
sp.l: Curled him and perfumed him,
But that was done with judgement, for he looks
Like one that purged perpetually; trust me,
That witches face of his is painted too,
And every ditch upon it buries more
Than would set off ten bawds, and all their tenants.

sp.speaker: Sos.
sp.l: See how it moves towards us.

sp.speaker: Nea.
sp.l: There's a salutation:
'Troth gentlemen, you have bestowed much travel
In training up your pupil.

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.l: Sir, great buildings
Require great labours, which yet we repent not,
Since for the countries good we have brought home
An absolute man.

sp.speaker: Unc.
sp.l: As any of his years,
Corinth can show you.

sp.speaker: Era.
sp.l: He's exceeding meager.

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.l: His contemplation —

sp.speaker: Unc.
sp.l: Besides, 'tis fit
Learners should be kept hungry.

sp.speaker: Nea.
sp.l: You all contemplate;
For three such wretched pictures of lean famine
I never saw together.

sp.speaker: Unc.
sp.l: We have fat minds sir,
And travelled to save charges. Do you think
'Twas fit a young and hopeful gentleman
Should be brought up a glutton? he's my ward,
Nor was there ever where I bore the bag
Any superfluous waste.

sp.speaker: Era.
sp.l: Pray you can it speak?

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.l: He knows all languages, but will use none,
They are all too big for his mouth, or else too little
T'express his great conceits: and yet of late
With some ippulsion he hath set down
In a strange method by the way of question,
And briefly, to all business whatsoever
That may concern a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Nea.
sp.l: Good sir, let's hear him.

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.l: Come on sir.

sp.speaker: Nea.
sp.l: They have taught him like an ape,
To do his tricks by signs: now he begins.

sp.speaker: Onos.
sp.l: When shall we be drunk together?

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.l: That's the first.

sp.speaker: Onos.
sp.l: Where shall we whore tonight ?

sp.speaker: Uncle.
sp.l: That ever follows.

sp.speaker: Era.
sp.l: 'Odds me, he now looks angry.

sp.speaker: Onos.
sp.l: Shall we quarrel?

sp.speaker: Nea.
sp.l: With me at no hand sir.

sp.speaker: Onos.
sp.l: Then let's protest.

sp.speaker: Era.
sp.l: Is this all?

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.l: These are sir, the four new virtues
That are in fashion: many a mile we measured
Before we could arrive unto this knowledge.

sp.speaker: Nea.
sp.l: You might have spared that labour, for at home here
There's little else in practice: ha? the Queen?
Good friends, for half an hour remove your motion,
Tomorrow willingly when we have more leisure
We'll look on him again.

sp.speaker: Onos.
sp.l: Did I not rarely?

sp.speaker: Uncle.
sp.l: Excellent well.

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.l: He shall have six plumbs for it. Exeunt.

div.stage: Anter Agenor, Leonidas, Theanor, Queen, Merione, Beliza, Euphanes, Crates, ladies, attendants with lights.

sp.speaker: Queen.
sp.l: How much my court is honoured princely brother
In your vouchasing it your longed for presence
Were tedious to repeat, since 'tis already
(And heartily) acknowledged; may the gods
That look into King's actions smile upon
The league we have concluded; and their justice
Find me out to revenge it if I break
One article.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: Great miracle of Queens,
How happy I esteem myself in being
Thought worthy to be numbered in the rank
Of your confederates, my love and best service
Shall teach the world hereafter: but this gift
With which you have confirmed it, is so far
Beyond my hopes and means ere to return,
That of necessity I must die obliged
To your unanswered bounty.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: The sweet lady
In blushes gives your highness thanks.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Believe it
On the Queen's word, she is a worthy one,
And I am so acquainted with her goodness,
That but for this peace that hath changed my purpose,
And to her more advancement, I should gladly
Have called her daughter.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Though I am deprived of
A blessing 'tis not in the fates to equal,
To show myself a subject as a son,
Here I give up my claim, and willingly
With mine own hand deliver you what once
I loved above myself; and from this hour
(For my affection yields now to my duty)
Vow never to solicit her.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: 'Tis well covered
Neanthes, and the rest. Exit Cra. nea. sos. Era.

sp.speaker: Quee.
sp.l: Nay, for this night
You must (For 'tis our country fashion sir)
Leave her to her devotions, in the morning
We'll bring you to the temple.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: How in this
Your highness honours me?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Sweet rest to all.

sp.speaker: Age.
sp.l: This kiss, and I obey you.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Please it your highness,
This is the gentleman.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: You are welcome home sir,
(Now as I live, one of a promising presence)
I have heard of you before, and you shall find
I'll know you better: find out something that
May do you good, and rest assured to have it.
Were you at Sparta lately?

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: Three days since
Madam I came from thence.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: 'Tis very late,
Good night my lord; do you sir follow me,
I must talk further with you.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.l: All rest with you. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Crates, Neanthes, Eraton, Sosicles disguised.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: She must pass through this cloister, suddenly
And boldly seize upon her.

sp.speaker: Nea.
sp.l: Where's the prince?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: He does expect us at the place I showed you.
I hear ones footing, peace, 'tis she;

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Now leave me,
I know the way, though Vesta witness with me
I never trod it with such fear: help, help.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: Stop her mouth close, out with the light, I'll guide you. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: To whom now shall I cry? What power thus kneel to?
And beg my ravished honour back upon me?
Deaf, deaf, you gods of goodness, deaf to me,
Deaf heaven to all my cries; deaf hope, deaf justice,
I am abused, and you that see all saw it;
Saw it, and smiled upon the villain did it:
Saw it, and gave him strength: why have I prayed to ye,
When all the world's eyes have been sunk in slumbers?
Why have I then poured out my tears? kneeled to ye?
And from the altar of a pure heart sent ye
Thoughts like, yourselves, white, innocent, vows purer
And of a sweeter flame than all earth's odours?
Why have I sung your praises, strewed your temples,
And crowned your holy priests with virgin roses?
Is it we hold ye powerful, to destroy us?
Believe, and honour ye, to see us ruined?
These tears of anger thus I sprinkle towards ye,
You that dare sleep secure whilst virgins suffer,
These stick like comets, blaze eternally,
Till with the wonder they have woken your justice,
And forced ye fear our curses, as we yours.
My shame still follows me, and still proclaims me;
He turns away in scorn, I am contemned too,
A more unmanly violence than the other;
Bitten, and flung away? Whate'er you are
Sir, you that have abused me, and now most basely
And sacrilegiously robbed this fair temple,
I fling all these behind me, but look upon me,
But one kind loving look, be what ye will,
So from this hour you will be mine, my husband;
And you his hand in mischief, I speak to you too,
Counsel him nobly now; you know the mischief,
The most unrighteous act he has done, persuade him,
Persuade him like a friend, knock at his conscience
Till fair repentance follow: yet be worthy of me,
And show yourself, if ever good thought guided ye,
You have had your foul will, make it yet fair with marriage;
Open yourself and take me, wed me now:Draws his dagger.
More fruits of villainy? your dagger? come
Ye are merciful, I thank ye for your medicine:
Is that too worthy too?
Devil, thou with him,
Thou penny bawd to his lust, will not that stir thee?
Do you work by tokens now? Be sure I live not,
For your own safeties knaves. I will sit patiently:
But as ye are true villains, the devils own servants,
And those he loves and trusts, make it as bloody
An act, of such true horror heaven would shake at,
'Twill show the braver: goodness hold my hope fast,
And in thy mercies look upon my ruins,
And then I am right: my eyes grow dead and heavy:
sp.stage: Enter six disguised, singing and dancing to a horrid music, and sprinkling water on her face.
sp.l: Wrong me no more as ye are men.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: She is fast.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: Away with her. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena secunda.
div.stage: Enter Agenor, and gentlemen with torches.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.l: Now gentlemen, the time's come now t'enjoy
That fruitful happiness my heart has longed for:
This day be happy called, and when old time
Brings it about each year, crowned with that sweetness
It gives me now, see every man observe it,
And laying all aside bears show of business,
Give this to joy and triumph: how sits my clothes?

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.l: Handsome, and wondrous well sir.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.l: Do they show richly?
For to those curious eyes even beauty envies,
I must not now appear poor, or low fashioned;
Methinks I am younger than I was, far younger;
And such a promise in my blood I feel now,
That if there may be a perpetual youth
Bestowed on man, I am that soul shall win it:
Does my hair stand well, lord how ill-favouredly
You have dressed me today? how baldly? why this cloak?

sp.speaker: 2 g●n
sp.l: Why 'tis the richest sir.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.l: And here ye have put me on
A pair of breeches look like a pair of bagpipes.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.l: Believe sir, they show bravely.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.l: Why these stockings?

sp.speaker: 2 gent
sp.l: Your leg appears —

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.l: Peuh I would have had 'em peach colour,
All young, and new about me: and this scarf here
A goodly thing: you have tricked me like a puppet.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.l: I'll undertake to rig forth a whole navy,
And with less labour than one man in love,
They are never pleased.

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.l: Methinks he looks well.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.l: Well
As man can look, as handsome: now do I wonder
He found not fault his nose was put on ugly,
Or his eyes looked too grey, and rail at us,
They are the waywards things, these lovers.

sp.speaker: 2 gent.
sp.l: All will be right
When once it comes to th' push.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.l: I would they were at it
For our own quiet sake.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.l: Come, wait upon me,
And bear yourselves like mine, my friends, and nobly. Ex.

div.head: Scaena tertia.
div.stage: Enter Theanor, Crates, and erates, bringing Merione.

sp.speaker: Erat.
sp.l: This is her brother's door.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: There lay her down then.
Lay her along: she is fast still.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: As forgetfulness.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: Be not you stirred now, but away to your mother,
Give all attendance, let no stain appear
Of fear, or doubt in your face: carry yourself confidently.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: But whither runs your drift now?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: When she wakes,
Either what's done will show a mere dream to her,
And carry no more credit: or say she find it,
Say she remember all the circumstances,
Twenty to one the shapes in which they were acted,
The horrors, and the still affrights we showed her,
Rising in wilder figures to her memory
Will run her mad, and no man guess the reason:
If all these fail, and that she rise up perfect,
And so collect herself, believe this sir,
Not knowing who it was that did this to her,
Nor having any power to guess; the thing done too,
Being the utter undoing of her honour
If it be known, and to the world's eye published,
Especially at this time when fortune courts her,
She must and will conceal it; nay, forget it,
The woman is no Lucrece; get you gone sir,
And as you would have more of this sport, fear not.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: I am confirmed, farewell.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: Farewell, away sir:
Disperse yourselves, and as you love his favour,
And that that crowns it, gold, no tongues amongst ye.
You know your charge, this way goes no suspicion. Exeu.

div.stage: Enter Agenor and Leonides, with two gent. with lights.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.l: You are stirring early sir.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: It was my duty
To wait upon your grace.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.l: How fares your sister,
My beauteous mistress, what is she ready yet?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: No doubt she'll lose no time sir, young maids in her way
Tread upon thorns, and think an hour an age
Till the priest has done his part, that theirs may follow:
I saw her not since yesterday ith' evening:
But sir, I am sure she is not slack; believe me,
Your grace will find a loving soul.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.l: A sweet one,
And so much joy I carry in the thought of it,
So great a happiness to know she is mine;
Believe me noble brother, that to express it
Methinks a tongue's a poor thing, can do nothing,
Imagination less: who's that that lies there?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Where sir?

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.l: Before the door, it looks like a woman:

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: This way I came abroad, but then there was nothing,
One of the maids o'erwatched belike.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.l: It may be.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: But methinks this is no fit place to sleep in.

sp.speaker: 1 gent.
sp.l: 'Tis sure a woman sir, she has jewels on too:
She fears no foul play sure.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Bring a torch hither,
Yet 'tis not perfect day: I should know those garments.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.l: How sound she sleeps?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: I am sorry to see this.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.l: Do you know her?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: And you now I am sure sir.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.l: My mistress, how comes this?

div.stage: Enter Queen, Theanor, Beliza, Euphanes, Neanthes, attendants.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: The Queen and her train?

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: You know my pleasure.

sp.speaker: Eup.
sp.l: And will be most careful.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Be not long absent, the suit you preferred
Is granted.

sp.speaker: Nea.
sp.l: This fellow mounts apace, and will
Tower o'er us like a falcon.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Good morrow to ye all, why stand ye wondering?
Enter the house sir, and bring out your mistress,
You must observe our ceremonies: what's the matter?
What's that ye stand at? How Merione?
Asleep i'th street? belike some sudden palsy
As she stepped out last night upon devotion,
To took her farewell of her virgin state,
The air being sharp and piercing, struck her suddenly:
See if she breathe.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: A little.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Wake her then,
'Tis sure a fit.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.l: She wakes herself,
Give room to her.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: See how the spirits struggle to recover,
And strongly reinforce their strengths; for certain
This was no natural sleep.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: I am of your mind madam.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: No son, it cannot be.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Pray heaven no trick in't;
Good soul she little merits such a mischief.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: She is broad awake now, and her sense clears up,
'Twas sure a fit; stand off.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: The Queen, my love here,
And all my noble friends? Why where am I?
How am I tranced, and moped? i'th street? Heaven bless me,
Shame to my sex; o'th ground too? O, I remember —

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: How wild she looks?

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.l: O my cold heart, how she trembles?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: O I remember, I remember.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: What's that?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: My shame, my shame, my shame: oh I remember
My never-dying shame.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Here has been villainy.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: I fear so to.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: You are no furies are ye?
No horrid shapes sent to affright me?

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.l: No sweet,
We are your friends: look up, I am Agenor,
Oh my Merione, that loves you dear:
And come to marry ye.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Sister, what ail ye?
Speak out your griefs, and boldly —

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.l: Something sticks here
Will choke ye else.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I hope it will.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Be free lady,
You have your loving friends about ye.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.l: Dear Merione,
By the unspotted love I ever bore ye,
By thine own goodness —

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: O 'tis gone, 'tis gone sir,
I am now I know not what: pray ye look not on me,
No name is left me, nothing to inherit
But that detested, base, and branded —

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.l: Speak it,
And how; diseases of most danger
Their causes once discovered are easily cured:
My fair Merione.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I thank your love sir;
When I was fair Merione, unspotted,
Pure, and unblasted in the bud you honoured,
White as the heart of truth, than prince Agenor,
Even then I was not worthy of your favour;
Wretch that I am, less worthy now of pity:
Let no good thing come near me, virtue fly me;
You that have honest noble names despise me,
For I am nothing now but a main pestilence
Able to poison all. Send those unto me
That have forgotten their names, ruined their fortunes,
Despised their honours; those that have been virgins
Ravished and wronged, and yet dare live to tell it.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Now it appears too plain.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Send those sad people
That hate the light, and curse society;
Whose thoughts are graves, and from whose eyes continually
Their melting souls drop out, send those to me;
And when their sorrows are most excellent,
So full that one grief more cannot be added,
My story like a torrent shall devour 'em.
Hark, it must out; but pray stand close together,
And let not all the world hear.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Speak it boldly.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: And royal lady, think but charitably,
Your grace has known my breeding.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Prithee speak it.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Is there no stranger here? send off your servants,
And yet it must be known: I shake.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.l: Sweet mistress.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I am abused, basely abused; do you guess yet?
Come close I'll tell ye plainer; I am whored,
Ravished, and robbed of honour.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: O the devil.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.l: What hellish slave was this?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: A wretch, a wretch,
A damned wretch: do you know the villain lady?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Not by guess?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: O no.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: It must be known.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Where was the place?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I know not neither.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.l: O heaven,
Is this the happy time? my hope to this come?

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Neither the man, nor circumstances?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: His tongue,
Did you not hear his tongue, no voice?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: None, none sir:
All I know of him was his violence.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.l: How came ye hither sweet?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I know not neither.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: A cunning piece of villainy.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: All I remember
Is only this: going to Vesta's temple
To give the goddess my last virgin prayers,
Near to that place I was suddenly surprised,
By five or six disguised, and from thence violently
To my dishonour haled: that act performed,
Brought back, but how, or whether, till I waked here. —

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: This is so monstrous the gods cannot suffer it;
I have not read in all the villainies
Committed by the most obdurate rascals,
An act so truly impious.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Would I knew him.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: He must be known, the devil cannot hide him.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: If all the art I have, or power can do it,
He shall be found, and such a way of justice
Inflicted on him: a lady wronged in my court,
And this way robbed, and ruined?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Be contented madam,
If he be above ground I will have him.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.l: Fair virtuous maid, take comfort yet and flourish,
In my love flourish: the stain was forced upon ye
None of your wills, nor yours; rise, and rise mine still,
And rise the same white, sweet, fair soul, I loved ye,
Take me the same.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I kneel and thank ye sir,
And I must say ye are truly honourable,
And dare confess my will yet still a virgin;
But so unfit and weak a cabinet
To keep your love and virtue in am I now,
That have been forced and broken, lost my lustre,
I mean this body, so corrupt a volume
For you to study goodness in, and honour,
I shall entreat your grace, confer that happiness
Upon a beauty sorrow never saw yet:
And when this grief shall kill me, as it must do,
Only remember yet ye had such a mistress;
And if ye then dare shed a tear, yet honour me:
Good gentlemen express your pities to me,
In seeking out this villainy; and my last suit
Is to your grace, that I may have your favour
To live a poor recluse nun with this lady,
From court and company, till heaven shall hear me,
And send me comfort, or death end my misery.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Take your own will, my very heart bleeds for thee.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.l: Farewell Merione, since I have not thee
I'll wed thy goodness, and thy memory.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: And I her fair revenge.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Away: let's follow it,
For he is so rank i'th wind we cannot miss him. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena quarta.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: Conon you are welcome home, ye are wondrous welcome,
Is this your first arrival?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Sir, but now
I reached the town.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: You're once more welcome then.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: I thank ye noble sir.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: Pray ye do me the honour
To make my poor house first —

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Pray sir excuse me,
I have not seen mine own yet; nor made happy
These longing eyes with those I love there: what's this a tavern?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: It seems so by the outside.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Step in here then,
And since it offers itself so freely to us,
A place made only for liberal entertainment,
Let's seek no further but make use of this,
And after the Greek fashion, to our friends,
Crown a round cup or two.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: Your pleasure sir.
Drawers, who waits within?

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.l: Anon, anon sir.

sp.speaker: Vintner
sp.l: Look into the lilly-pot: why mark there;
You are welcome gentlemen; heartily welcome
My noble friend.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: Let's have good wine mine host,
And a fine private room.

sp.speaker: Vintner
sp.l: Will ye be there sir?
What is't you'll drink? I'll draw your wine myself:
Cushions ye knaves: why when?

sp.speaker: Drawer
sp.l: Anon, anon sir.

sp.speaker: Vintner
sp.l: Chios, or Lebos, Greek?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: Your best and neatest.

sp.speaker: Vintner
sp.l: I'll draw ye that shall dance.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: Away, be quick then. Exit vintner.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: How does your brother sir, my noble friend
The good Euphanes? in all my course of travel
I met not with a gentleman so furnished
In gentleness and courtesy; believe sir,
So many friendly offices I received from him,
So great, and timely, and enjoyed his company
In such an open and a liberal sweetness,
That when I dare forget him —

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: He's in good health sir,
But you will find him a much altered man,
Grown a great courtier sir.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: He's worthy of it.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: A man drawn up, that leaves no print behind him
Of what he was: those goodnesses you speak of
That have been in him, those that you call freedoms,
Societies, and sweetness, look for now sir,
You'll find no shadows of them left, no sound,
The very air he has lived in altered: now behold him,
And you shall see a thing walk by, look big upon ye,
And cry for place; I am the Queens, give room there:
If you bow low, may be he'll touch the bonnet,
Or fling a forced smile at ye for a favour.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: He is your brother sir.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: These forms put off,
Which travel, and court holy-water sprinkle on him,
I dare accept, and know him: you'll think it strange sir,
That even to me, to me his natural brother,
And one by birth he owes a little honour too —
(But that's all one) come give me some wine, mine host,
Here's to your fair return.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: I wonder at it,
But sure he has found a nature not worth owning
In this way; else I know he is tender carried.
I thank ye sir: and now durst I presume
For all you tell me of these alterations,
And stops in his sweet nature, which till I find so,
I have known him now so long, and looked so through him,
You must give me leave to be a little faithless:
I say for all these, if you please to venture
I'll lay the wine we drink, let me send for him
(Even I that am the poorest of his fellowship)
But by a boy oth' house too, let him have business,
Let him attend the Queen, nay let his mistress
Hold him betwixt her arms, he shall come to me,
And shall drink with me too; love me, and heartily,
Like a true honest man bid me welcome home.
I am confident.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: You will lose.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: You'll stand toth' wager?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Go boy, and tell Euphanes.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: He's now gone up the street sir,
With a great train of gallants.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: What think you now sir?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Go, and overtake him,
Commend my love unto him: my name is Conon,
Tell him I am new arrived, and where I am,
And would request to see him presently:
Ye see I use old dudgeon phrase to draw him.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: I'll hang and quarter when you draw him hither.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Away boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: I am gone sir. Exit.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Here's to you now,
And you shall find his travel has not stopped him
As you suppose, nor altered any freedom,
But made him far more clear and excellent;
It draws the grossness off the understanding,
And renders active and industrious spirits:
He that knows most men's manners, must of necessity
Best know his own, and mend those by example:
'Tis a dull thing to travel like a mill-horse,
Still in the place he was born in, lamed and blinded;
Living at home is like it: pure and strong spirits
That like the fire still covet to fly upward,
And to give fire as well as take it; cased up, and mewed here
I mean at home, like lusty mettled horses,
Only tied up in stables, to please their masters,
Beat out their fiery lives in their own litters,
Why do not you travel sir?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: I have no belief in't
I see so many strange things, half unhatched, to
Return, those that went out men, and good men,
They look like potched eggs with the souls sucked out,
Empty and full of wind: all their affections
Are baked in rye crust, to hold carriage
From this good town toth' other: and when they are opened,
They are so ill cooked and mouldy —

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Ye are pleasant.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: I'll show ye a pack of these: I have 'em for ye,
That have been long in travel too.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Please you sir.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: You know the merchants walk, boy?

sp.speaker: 2 boy.
sp.l: Very well.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: And you remember those gentlemen were here
The other day with me?

sp.speaker: 2 boy.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: Then go thither,
For there I am sure they are, pray 'em come hither,
(And use my name) I would be glad to see 'em.

sp.speaker: 1 boy.
sp.l: Your brother's coming in sir.

sp.speaker: Vintner
sp.l: Odds my passion,
Out with the plate ye knaves: bring the new cushions,
And wash those glasses I set by for high days,
Perfume the rooms along, why sirrah.

sp.speaker: 1 boy.
sp.l: Here sir.

sp.speaker: Vintner
sp.l: Bid my wife make herself ready handsomely,
And put on her best apron: it may be
The noble gentleman will look upon her.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: Where is he boy?

sp.speaker: Vintner
sp.l: Your worship's heartily welcome,
It joys my very heart to see ye here sir.
The gentleman that sent for your honour —

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: O good mine host.

sp.speaker: Vintner
sp.l: To my poor homely house, an't like your honour.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: I thank thine honour good mine host, where is he?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: What think ye now? my best Euphanes.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: Conon, welcome my friend, my noble friend how is it?
Are you in safety come, in health?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: All health, all safety,
Riches, and all that makes content and happiness
Now I am here I have: how have you fared sir?

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: Well, I thank heaven, and never nearer friend
To catch at great occasion.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Indeed I joy in't.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: Nor am I for myself born in these fortunes,
In truth I love my friends.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: You were noble ever.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: I thought you have not known me.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: Yes, ye are my brother,
My elder brother too, would your affections
Were able but to ask that love I owe to ye,
And as I give, preserve it: here friend Conon,
To your fair welcome home.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Dear sir, I thank ye,
Fill it toth' brim, boy: Crates.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: I'll pledge you,
But for that glorious comet lately fired.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Fie, fie sir, fie.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: Nay, let him take his freedoms,
He stirs not me I vow to ye: much less stains me.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: Sir, I cannot talk with that neat travelling tongue.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: As I live, he has the worst belief in men abroad.
I am glad I am come home.

sp.speaker: 2 boy.
sp.l: Here are the gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: O let 'em enter: now you that trust in travel,
And make sharp beards, and little breeches deities,
You that enhance the daily price of toothpicks,
And hold there is no homebred happiness,
Behold a model of your minds and actions.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: Though this be envious, yet done ith' way of mirth,
I am content to thank ye for't.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: 'Tis well yet.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: Let the mask enter.

div.stage: Enter Onos, his uncle and tutor.

sp.speaker: Onos.
sp.l: A pretty tavern i'faith, of a fine structure.

sp.speaker: Unc.
sp.l: Bear yourself like a gentleman, here's six pence,
And be sure you break no glasses.

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.l: Hark ye pupil,
Go as I taught you, hang more upon your hams,
And put your knees out bent: there, yet a little:
Now I beseech ye, be not so improvident
To forget your travelling pace, 'tis a main posture,
And to all unaired gentlemen will betray you:
Play with your Pisa beard: why, where's your brush pupil?
He must have a brush sir.

sp.speaker: Unc.
sp.l: More charge yet?

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.l: Here, take mine,
These elements of travel he must not want sir.

sp.speaker: Uncle
sp.l: Ma foy, he has had some nineteen pence in elements,
What would you more?

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.l: Durus me hercle pater.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: What monsieur onos, the very pump of travel,
Sir, as I live you have done me the greatest kindness,
Oh my fair sir, Lampree, the careful uncle
To this young hopeful issue; monsieur tutor too,
The father to his mind; come, come, let's hug boys,
Why what a bunch of travel do I embrace now,
Methinks I put a girdle about Europe;
How has the boy profited?

sp.speaker: Uncle
sp.l: He has enough sir,
If his too fiery mettle do not mar it.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Is he not thrifty yet?

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.l: That's all his fault,
Too bounteous minded being under age too,
A great consumer of his stock in pippins ▪
Had ever a hot stomach.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Come hither Onos,
Will you love me for this fine apple?

sp.speaker: Onos.
sp.l: We.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: And will ye be ruled by me sometimes?

sp.speaker: Onos.
sp.l: I'faith I will.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: That's a good boy.

sp.speaker: Unc.
sp.l: Pray give me not the child so much fruit,
He's of a raw complexion.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: You monsieur hard egg,
Do you remember me? Do you remember
When you and your consort travelled through Hungary?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: He's in that circuit still.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: Do you remember
The cantle of immortal cheese ye carried with ye,
The half cold cabbage, in a leather satchel,
And those invincible eggs that would lie in your bowels
A fortnight together, and then turn to bedstaves;
Your sour milk that would choke an Irish man,
And bread was baked in Caesar's time for the army?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Providence, providence.

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.l: The soul of travel.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: Can the boy speak yet?

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.l: Yes, and as fine a gentleman,
I thank my able knowledge, he has arrived at,
Only a little sparing of his language,
Which every man of observation —

sp.speaker: Unc.
sp.l: And of as many tongues.

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.l: Pray be content sir,
You know you are for the bodily part, the purse,
I for the magazine, the mind.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: Come hither springal.

sp.speaker: On.
sp.l: That in the almain tongue signifies a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Fuph.
sp.p: What think you of the forms of Italy or Spain?

sp.speaker: Onos.
sp.l: I love mine own country Pippin.

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.l: Nobly answered,
Born for his country first.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: A great philosopher:
What horses do you prefer?

sp.speaker: Onos.
sp.l: The white horse sir,
There were I lie; honest and a just beast,

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.l: O caput lepidum: a child to say this,
Are these figures for the mouths of infants?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Onos, what wenches?
Come, tell me true.

sp.speaker: On.
sp.l: I cannot speak without book.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: When shall we have one, ha?

sp.speaker: On.
sp.l: Steal me from mine uncle,
For look you, I am broke out horribly
For want of fleshly physic: they say I am too young,
And that 'twill spoil my growth ▪ but could you help me?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Meet me tomorrow man, no more.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: You think now
Ye have opened such a shame to me of travel,
By showing these thin cubs: ye have honoured us
Against your will, proclaimed us excellent:
Three frails of sprats carried from mart, to mart,
Are as much meat as these, to more use travelled;
A bunch of bloated fools: methinks your judgement
Should look abroad sometimes without your envy.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: Such are most of you: so I take my leave,
And when you find your women's favour fail,
'Tis ten to one you'll know yourself, and seek me
Upon a better muster of your manners.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: This is not handsome sir.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: Pray take your pleasure,
You wound the wind as much —

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: Come you with me,
I have business for you presently: there's for your wine,
I must confess I lost it.

sp.speaker: On.
sp.l: Shall I steal to ye
And shall we see the wench?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: A dainty one.

sp.speaker: On.
sp.l: And have a dish of pippins?

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: What a peck man.

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.l: Will you wait sir.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Pray let's meet oftener gentlemen,
I would not lose ye.

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.l: O sweet sir.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Do you think I would,
Such noted men as you?

sp.speaker: Onos, Unc. tutor
sp.l: We are your servants. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: That thing they would keep in everlasting nonage,
My brother for his own ends has thrust on
Upon my mistress, 'tis true, he shall be rich
If ever he can get that rogue his uncle
To let him be of years to come to inherit it,
Now what the main drift is —

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Say ye so? no more words,
I'll keep him company till he be of years,
Though it be a hundred years, but I'll discover it;
And ten to one I'll cross it too.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: You are honest,
And I shall study still your love: farewell sir,
For these few hours I must desire your pardon,
I have business of importance: once a day
At least I hope you'll see me: I must see you else:
So, once more ye are welcome.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: All my thanks sir,
And when I leave to love you, life go from me. Exeunt.

div.head: Scaena prima.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: Why sir, the kingdoms his, and no man now
Can come to Corinth, or from Corinth go
Without his licence; he puts up the tithes
Of every office through Achaia;
From courtier to the carter hold of him:
Our lands, our liberties, nay very lives
Are shut up in his closet, and let loose
But at his pleasure; books, and all discourse
Have now no patron, nor direction.
But glorified Euphanes: our cups are guilty
That quench our thirsts, if not unto his health:
O, I could eat my heart, and fling away
My very soul for anguish: gods, nor men
Should tolerate such disproportion.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: And yet is he beloved: whether't be virtue,
Or seeming virtue which he makes the cloak
To his ambition.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: Be it which it will:
Your highness is to tame, your eyes too filmed
To see this, and sit still: the lion should not
Tremble to hear the bellowing of the bull;
Nature excuse me, though he be my brother,
You are my country's father, therefore mine:
One parallel line of love I bend on him,
All lines of love and duty meet in you
As in their centre: therefore hear, and weigh
What I shall speak: you know the Queen your mother
Did from a private state your father raise,
So all your royalty you hold from her;
She is older than she was, therefore more doting,
And what know we but blindness of her love
(That hath from underneath the foot of fortune
Set, even Euphanes' foot, on fortune's head)
Will take him by the hand, and cry, leap now
Into my bed; 'tis but a trick of age;
Nothing impossible.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: What do you infer on this?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: Your pardon sir:
With reverence to the Queen; yet why should I
Fear to speak plain what pointeth to your good?
A good old widow is a hungry thing,
(I speak of other widows, not of Queens.)

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Speak to thy purpose.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: I approach it: sir,
Should young Euphanes clasp the kingdom thus,
And please the good old lady some one night;
What might not she be wrought to put on you,
Quite to supplant your birth? neither is she
Past children, as I take it.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Crates, thou shak'st me;
Thou, that dost hate thy brother for my love,
In my love find one; henceforth be my brother:
This giant I will fell beneath the earth;
I will shine out, and melt his artful wings:
Euphanes, from my mother's sea of favours
Spreads like a river, and runs calmly on,
Secure yet from my storms; like a young pine
He grows up planted under a fair oak,
Whose strong large branches yet does shelter him,
And every traveller admires his beauty;
But like a wind, I'll work into his cranks,
Trouble his stream, and drown all vessels that
Ride on his greatness: under my mother's arms,
Like to a stealing tempest will I search,
And rend his root from her protection.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Ay, now Theanor speaks like prince Theanor.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: But how shall we provoke him to our snares?
He has a temper malice cannot move
To exceed the bounds of judgement; he is so wise,
That we can pick no cause to affront him.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: No?
What better than his crossing your intent?
The suit I had to ye? Conon's forfeit state
(Before he travelled) for a riot, he
Hath from your mother got restored to him:

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Durst he? What is this Conon?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: One that hath,
As people say, in foreign pleasured him.
sp.stage: Enter Onos, uncle, tutor, Neanthes, Sosicles, Eraton.
sp.l: But now no more;
They have brought the travellers I told you of,
That's the sweet youth, that is my brother's rival,
That curls his head, for he has little hair,
And paints his vizor, for it is no face,
That so desires to follow you, my lord:
Show 'em some countenance, and it will beget
Our sport at least.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: What villainous crabtree legs he makes?
His shins are full of true-love knots.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: His legs were ever villainous, since I knew him.

sp.speaker: Era.
sp.l: Faith his uncle's shanks are somewhat the better.

sp.speaker: Nea.
sp.l: But is't possible he should believe he is not of age?
He is 50, man, in's jubilee I warrant: 'slight, he
Looks older than a groat, the very stamp on's face is why
Worn out with handling.

sp.speaker: Sos.
sp.l: Why I tell you all men believe it when they hear him speak,
He utters such single matter in so infantly a voice.

sp.speaker: Nea.
sp.l: He looks as like a fellow that I have seen accommodate
Gentlemen with tobacco in our theatres.

sp.speaker: Onos.
sp.l: Most illustrious prince.

sp.speaker: Era.
sp.l: A pox on him, he is guelt, how he trebles?

sp.speaker: Onos.
sp.l: I am a gentleman a both sides.

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.p: He means (So't please your highness) both by father and mother.

sp.speaker: Sos.
sp.l: Thou a gentleman? thou an ass.

sp.speaker: Nea.
sp.l: He is never the farther from being a getl. I assure you.

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.l: May it please your grace, I am another.

sp.speaker: Nea.
sp.l: He is another ass he says, I believe him.

sp.speaker: Uncle.
sp.l: We be three, heroical prince.

sp.speaker: Nea.
sp.l: Nay then we must have the picture of 'em, and the
Word nos sumus.

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.l: That have travailed all parts of the globe together.

sp.speaker: Unc.
sp.p: For my part, I have seen the vicissitude of fortune before.

sp.speaker: Onos.
sp.p: Peace uncle, for though you speak a little better than I —

sp.speaker: Nea.
sp.l: 'Tis a very little, in truth.

sp.speaker: Onos.
sp.l: Yet we must both give place, as they say, to the best speaker
The tutor.

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.l: Yet since it hath pleased your radiance to decline so low, as on us,
Poor and unworthy dunghills. —

sp.speaker: Nea.
sp.l: What a stinking knaves this?

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.p: Our peregrination was ne'er so felicitated, as since we entered the line of your gracious favour, under whose beamy aspect, and by which infallible mathematical compass, may we but hereafter presume to sail, our industries have reached their desired termination and period; and we shall voluntarily sacrifice our lives to your resplendent eyes, both the altars and fires of our devoted offerings.

sp.speaker: Onos.
sp.l: O divine tutor!

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: Can you hold sir?

sp.speaker: Era.
sp.p: He has spoken this very speech to some whore in Corinth.

sp.speaker: Nea.
sp.p: A plague on him for a sustain dictionary; on my conscience this is the Ulyssean traveler that sent home his image riding upon elephants to the great mogul.

sp.speaker: Sos.
sp.p: The same: his wit is so huge, naught but an elephant could carry him.

sp.speaker: Era.
sp.l: So heavy you mean.

sp.speaker: Nea.
sp.p: These three, are e'en the finest one fool tripartite, that was ere discovered.

sp.speaker: Sos.
sp.l: Or a treatise of famine divided into three branches.

sp.speaker: Era.
sp.l: The prince speaks.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: I thank ye for your loves; but as I told you,
I have so little means, to do for those
Few followers I have already, that
I would have none shipwreck themselves, and fortune,
Upon my barren shelf: sue to Euphanes.
For he is prince, and Queen, I would have no man
Curse me in his old age.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: Alas sir, they desire to follow you
But afar off, the farther off the better.

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.p: I sir, an't be seven mile off, so we may but follow you, only to countenance us in the confronts and affronts, which (According to your highness' will) we mean on all occasions to put upon the lord Euphanes.

sp.speaker: Onos.
sp.p: He shall not want gibing nor jeering, I warrant him; if he do, I'll forswear wit.

sp.speaker: Nea.
sp.p: It has forsworn thee, 'I'll swear, it is the ancient enemy to thy house.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.p: Well, be it so; I here receive ye, for my followers a great way off.

sp.speaker: Nea.
sp.l: Seven miles, my lord, no further.

sp.speaker: Onos.
sp.p: By what time, sir, (By this measure) may I come to follow him in his chamber?

sp.speaker: Nea.
sp.l: Why when his chamber, sir, is seven miles long.

div.stage: Enter Euphanes, Conon, page, gent. attendants.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Make way there, for my lord Euphanes.

sp.speaker: Cro.
sp.l: Look sir, Jove appears,
The peacock of our state, that spreads a train
Brighter than Iris blushes after rain.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: You need not thank me Conon, in your love
You antedated what I can do for you,
And I in gratitude was bound to this,
And am to much more: and whate'er he be
Can with unthankfulness assoil me, let him
Dig out mine eyes, and sing my name in verse ▪
In ballad verse at every drinking-house,
And no man be so charitable to lend me
A dog to guide my steps.

sp.speaker: Nea.
sp.l: Haile to Euphanes.

sp.speaker: Sos.
sp.l: Mighty Euphanes.

sp.speaker: Era.
sp.l: The great prince Euphanes.

sp.speaker: Tutor
sp.l: Key of the court, and jewel of the Queen.

sp.speaker: Unc.
sp.l: Sol in our firmament.

sp.speaker: Onos.
sp.l: Pearl in the state's eye.

sp.speaker: Nea.
sp.l: Being a black man.

sp.speaker: Era.
sp.l: Mistress of the land.

sp.speaker: Nea.
sp.l: Our humble, humble poor petitions are,
That we may hold our places.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: May we?

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: Yes; be you malicious knaves still: and you fools.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: This is the princes, and your brother's spite.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: I know't, but will not know't it.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Yonder they are,
Who's fine child's this?

sp.speaker: Unc.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Onos.
sp.l: Uncle, le' be,
Let him alone, he is a mighty prince.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: I ask your highness' pardon: I protest
By Jupiter I saw you not.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Humh, it may be so,
You have raised such mountains 'twixt your eyes and me,
That I am hidden quite: what do ye mean sir?
You much forget yourself.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: I should much more,
Not to remember my due duty to your grace;
I know not wherein I have so transgressed
My service to your highness, to deserve
This rigour and contempt, not from you only
But from your followers, with the best of whom
I was an equal in my lowest ebb:
Beseech you sir, respect me as a gentleman,
I will be never more in heart to you:
Five fair descents I can derive myself,
From father's worthy both in arts and arms.
I know your goodness companies your greatness
But that you are perverted: royal sir,
I am your humblest subject, use your pleasure,
But do not give protection to the wrongs
Of these subordinate slaves, whom I could crush
By that great destined favour, which my mistress
And your majestic mother deigns to me,
But in respect of you: I know lean envy
Waits ever on the steps of virtue advanced:
But why your mother's grace gets me disgrace,
Or renders me a slave to bear these wrongs
I do not know.
O mediocrity,
Thou priceless jewel, only mean men have
But cannot value; like the precious gem,
Found in the muckhill by the ignorant cock.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Your creamy words but cozen: how durst you
Intercept me so lately to my mother?
And what I meant your brother, you obtained
Unto the forfeiture again.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: Your answer to that my lord, my brother.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: May I perish
If ere I heard you intended such a suit,
Though 'twould have stuck an ignominious brand
Upon your highness, to have given your servant
A gentleman's whole state of worth and quality,
Confiscate only for a youthful brawl.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Your rudiments are too saucy: teach your page.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Ay, so are all things but your flatterers.

sp.speaker: Onos.
sp.l: Hold you your prating.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: You know where you are, you fleeten face.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: Yet sir to appease and satisfy your anger,
Take what you please from me, and give it him
In lieu of this: you shall not take it neither,
I freely will impart it, half my state,
Which brother if you please —

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: I'll starve in chains first,
Eat my own arms.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: O that you saw yourself:
You never made me such offer in my poorness,
And 'cause (To do you ease) I sought not to you
You thus malign me; yet your nature must not
Corrupt mine, nor your rude examples lead me:
If mine can mend you, I shall joy; you know
I fear you not: you have seen me proved a man
In every way of fortune, 'tis my comfort
I know no more such brothers in the world
As Crates is.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Nor I such as Euphanes:
The temper of an angel reigns in thee.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: Your royal mother sir, (I had forgotten)
Entreats your presence.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: You have done her errand,
I may do yours. Exit.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: Let it be truth my lord.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Crates, I'll question you for this.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: Pish, your worst. Exit.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Away you hounds after your scent.

sp.speaker: Onos.
sp.l: Come, we'll scorn to talk to 'em: now they are gone,
We'll away too. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Why bear you this my lord?

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: To show the passive fortitude the best;
Virtues a solid rock, whereat being aimed
The keenest darts of envy, yet unhurt
Her marble heroes stand, built of such bases,
Whilst they recoil, and wound the shooter's faces.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: My lord, the Queen.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Gentle Euphanes, how,
How dost thou honest lord? o how I joy
To see what I have made, like a choice workman,
That having framed a masterpiece, doth reap
An universal commendations.
Princes are gods in this. I'll build thee yet,
(The good foundation so pleases me)
A story or two higher; let dogs bark,
They are fools that hold them dignified by blood,
They should be only made great that are good.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: Oraculous madam.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Sirrah, I was thinking
If I should marry thee, what merry tales
Our neighbour islands would make of us;
But let that pass, you have a mistress
That would forbid our banes: troth I have wished
A thousand times that I had been a man,
Than I might sit a day with thee alone,
And talk,
But as I am I must not; there's no skill
In being good, but in not being thought ill.
Sirrah, who's that?

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: So't please your majesty
Conon, the friend I sued for.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: 'Tis dispatched.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Gracious madam,
I owe the gods and you my life.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: I thank you,
I thank you heartily; and I do think you
A very honest man, he says you are:
But now I'll chide thee; what's the cause my son,
For my eye's everywhere , and I have heard,
So insolently does thee contumelies
Passed sufferance (I am told) yet you complain not,
As if my justice were so partial
As not to right the meanest: credit me,
I'll call him to a strict account, and fright
By his example, all that dare curb me
In any thing that's just: I sent you for him.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: Humbly he did return, he would wait on you:
But let me implore your majesty, not to give
His highness any check, for worthless me;
They are court cankers, and not counsellors
That thus inform you: they do but hate the prince,
And would subvert me: I should curse my fortune
Even at the highest, to be made the gin
To unscrew a mother's love unto her son:
Better had my pale flame in humble shades
Been spent unseen, then to be raised thus high,
Now to be thought a meteor to the state,
Portending ruin and contagion:
Beseech you then rest satisfied, the prince
Is a most noble natured gentleman,
And never did to me but what I took
As favours from him, my blown billows must not
Strive 'gainst my shore, that should confine me; nor
Justle with rocks to break themselves to pieces.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Well, thou'rt the composition of a god:
My lion, lamb, my eaglet, and my dove,
Whose soul runs clearer than Diana's fount,
Nature picked several flowers from her choice banks
And bound 'em up in thee, sending thee forth
A posy for the bosom of a Queen.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.l: The prince attends you.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Farewell my good lord,
My honest man; stay, hast no other suit?
I prithee tell me; sirrah, thine eye speaks
As if thou hadst: out with it modest fool.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: With favour madam, I would crave your leave
To marry, where I am bound in gratitude,
The immediate means she was to all my being:
Nor do I think your wisdom sacred Queen
Fetters in favours, taking from me so
The liberty that meanest men enjoy.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: To marry? you are a fool: thou'st angered me:
Leave me, I'll think on't:Exit Euph. and Conon.
Only to try thee this, for though I love thee,
I can subdue myself: but she that can
Enjoy thee, doth enjoy more than a man.
Nay rise without a blessing, or kneel still:
What's sir the reason you oppose me thus,
And seek to darken what I would have shine?
Eclipse a fire much brighter than thyself,
Making your mother not a competent judge
Of her own actions?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: Gracious madam, I
I have done no more than what in royalty
(And to preserve your fame) was fit to do:
Heard you the people's talk of you, and him
You favour so, his greatness, and your love,
The pity given to me, you would excuse me,
They prate as if he did dishonour you:
And what know I, but his own lavish tongue
Has uttered some such speeches; he is called
The King of Corinth.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: They are traitors all:
I wear a crystal casement 'fore my heart,
Through which each honest eye may look in to't:
Let it be prospect unto all the world,
I care not this.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: This must not be my way;
Your pardon gracious madam: these incitements
Made me not show so clear a countenance
Upon the lord Euphanes as I would:
Which since your majesty affects so grievously
I'll clear the black cloud of it, and henceforth
Vow on this knee all love and grace to him.

sp.speaker: Queen
sp.l: Rise with my blessing, and to prove this true,
Bear him from me this cabinet of jewels
In your own person, tell him, for his marrying
He may dispose him how, and when he please. Exit Quee.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: I shall discharge my duty and your will.
Crates?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: I have heard all my lord, how luckily
Fate pops her very spindle in our hands:
This marriage with Beliza you shall cross,
Then have I one attempt for Lamprias more
Upon this Phaeton: where's Merione's ring,
That in the rape you took from her?

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: 'Tis here.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: In and effect our purpose: you my lord
Shall disobey your mother's charge, and send
This cabinet by some servant of her own,
That what succeeds may have no reference
Unto your highness.

sp.speaker: The.
sp.l: On, my engine on.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.l: Now, if we be not struck by heavens own hand,
We'll ruin him, and on his ruins stand. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.l: These heavy airs feed sorrow in her lady,
And nourish it too strongly; like a mother
That spoils her child with giving on't the will.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Some lighter note. A lighter song.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: How like a hill of snow she sits, and melts
Before the unchaste fire of others lust?
What heart can see her passion and not break?

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.l: Take comfort gentle madam; you know well
Even actual sins committed without will,
Are neither sins nor shame, much more compelled;
Your honour's no whit less, your chastity
No whit impaired, for fair Merione
Is more a virgin yet then all her sex:
Alas, 'tis done; why burn these tapers now?
Wicked and frantic creatures joy in night.

sp.speaker: Leo.
sp.l: Imagine fair Merione had dreamed
She had been ravished, would she sit thus then
Excruciate?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Oh.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Fie, fie, how fond is this?
What reason for this surfeit of remorse?
How many that have done ill, and proceed,
Women that take degrees in wantonness,
Commence, and rise in rudiments of lust,
That feel no scruple of this tenderness?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Pish.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Nor are you matches in mishap, even I
Do bear an equal part of misery;
That love, beloved, a man, the crown of men,
Whom I have friended, and how raised 'tis better
That all do know and speak it then myself:
When he sailed low I might have made him mine,
Now at his full gale, it is questionable
If ever I o'ertake him.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.l: Wherefore sits
My Phebe shadowed in a sable could?
Those pearly drops which thou lets't fall like beads,
Numbering on them thy vestal orisons
Alas are spent in vain: I love thee still,
In midst of all these showers thou sweetlier sentest,
Like a green meadow on an April day,
In which the sun and west-wind play together,
Striving to catch and drink the balmy drops.

sp.speaker: Servant
sp.l: The lord Euphanes' madam. Exit Mer.

sp.speaker: Ag.
sp.l: Poor Merione,
She loathes the light, and men. Exit.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: The virtuous gods preserve my mistress.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: O my most honoured lord, those times are changed.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: Let times and men change, could heaven change, Euphanes
Should never change, to be devoted ever
To fair Beliza, should my load of honours,
Or any grace which you were author of
Detract mine honour, and diminish grace?
The gods forbid: you here behold your servant,
Your creature, gentle lady, whose sound sleeps
You purchased for him: whose food you paid for,
Whose garments were your charge, whose first preferment
You founded: then, what since the gracious Queen
Hath, or can rear, is upon your free land,
And you are mistress of.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Mock me not gentle lord,
You shine now in too high a sphere for me,
We are planets now disjoined for ever: yet
Poor superstitious innocent that I am,
Give leave that I may lift my hands, and love
Not in idolatry, but perfect zeal:
For credit me, I repent nothing I have done,
But were it to begin would do the same.

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: There are two seas in Corinth, and two Queens,
And but there, not two such in the spacious universe;
I came to tender you the man you have made,
And like a thankful stream to retribute
All you my ocean have enriched me with.
You told me once you'd marry me.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.l: Another mock? you were wont to play fairplay,
You scorn poor helps; he that is sure to win,
May slight mean hearts, whose hand commands the Queen

sp.speaker: Euph.
sp.l: Let me be held the knave through all the stock
When I do slight my mistress; you know well
The gracious inclination of the Queen,
